Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Infra-red Control of Electron Transfer Mechanisms
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this collaborative project supported by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor David N. Beratan of Duke University and Professor Igor Rubtsov of Tulane University will
develop methods to control electron transfer reactions, and to develop approaches to manipulate the strength of the electronic communication between molecules that influences the rate of electron transfer. The Beratan group will employ quantum and statistical mechanical theories to design, analyze and interpret inelastic electron-transfer kinetics in molecules with bridge-localized vibrational modes. The goal is to develop interpretive and predictive descriptions of intramolecular inelastic electron-tunneling in a variety of molecules containing an electron donor, a rigid bridge, and an electron acceptor. The Rubtsov group at Tulane will develop ultrafast laser and multi-dimensional infrared spectroscopic methods to examine analogies between the double slit electron transmission experiment and the molecular electron-transfer problem.

This work will a broad impact in developing intuition that may lead to applications in optical communication and solar energy harvesting. Professors Beratan and Rubtsov are promoting science education by providing summer research opportunities to economically disadvantaged and historically underrepresented groups. A new course cluster for first-year students is under development to examine the fundamental philosophical foundations of science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Charge transfer processes lie at the heart of bioenergetics, energy science, and nanoscience.   Developing strategies of manipulating the charge flow outcome using infra-red (IR) radiation is very attractive. The objective of this program is to understand how to manipulate, using IR radiation, the reaction outcome in a desired way via perturbing reaction coordinate motion and electronic coupling strength. Three-pulse femtosecond laser spectroscopy was used to measure the electron transfer (ET) rate modulation, where electronic excitation initiated the ET reaction was followed by excitation of vibrational mode(s) at the bridge connecting the donor and acceptor. The ET rates were measured by a probing laser pulse, either in the mid-IR or in the visible spectral range. Such spectroscopic approach permits isolating the effect of different vibrational modes excitation on the ET rate. Teaming up with theoretical group of Prof. Beratan at Duke University, several molecular systems were successfully studied. The first experiments, pursued by the team in collaboration with Prof. Lawrence at Xavier University in New Orleans, used infra-red perturbation of the hydrogen bonded bridge between organic donor and acceptor units (Fig. 1A). The influence of IR excitation on the ET kinetics was measured to be on the scale of a 60% rate effect: a novel finding, but one of moderate size. In collaboration with the Prof. Schmehl group at Tulane University, rate modulations in transition metal Re(I) complexes as large as 28% were found in the IR-excited species (Fig. 1B). The last 12 months have seen a burst of interest around the world in our aim of establishing IR control of charge transfer reactions, as our ideas have begun to find traction in other research groups.  Importantly, the group of Prof. Julia Weinstein at the University of Sheffield in the UK found that the yield of ET products from the excited state of a Pt species can be switched off with IR by directing the excited state towards nonradiative decay and intersystem crossing, Fig. 1C. This growing body of work has received recent attention in Physics Today (Miller, 2015, 68,(3),10) and Nature Chemistry (Rubtsov, 2015, 7, 683).

The intellectual merit of the program stems from learning how to use IR radiation to modulate the tunneling pathways and reaction coordinate motion (Fig. 2) in electron transfer reactions. Establishing the fundamental principles needed to manipulate reactions with IR excitation could impact a broad class or reactions that take center stage in solar energy harvesting, nanoscience, and molecular electronics. The studies are expected to advance fundamental understanding of ET reactions with potentially broad and transformative impact across the molecular disciplines that rely on charge transport events. 

The broader impact of the project include training, at Tulane alone, of 7 graduate students and two undergraduates in a highly interdisciplinary field involving experimental physical chemistry (Tulane), theoretical chemistry (Duke) and inorganic/organic chemistry (UT Austin, Xavier University, Duke, Tulane). The PI developed a graduate course on modern spectroscopy and taught it in Spring of 2014 and Spring of 2015. He also developed a laboratory unit on two-dimensional infrared spectroscopy for undergraduates within the class on Instrumental Analysis, which was taught 4 times over 5 year of the project.
